title: Cervical Artery Dissection
icd10: I63.00 (Cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of unspecified precerebral artery)
I63.20 (Cerebral infarction due to unspecified occlusion or stenosis of unspecified precerebral arteries)
I63.139 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of unspecified carotid artery)
scope: ** Acute and subacute cervical artery dissection (carotid and vertebral) in adults — covers spontaneous and traumatic etiologies, initial evaluation, imaging diagnosis (CTA, MRA with fat saturation, conventional angiography), antithrombotic therapy (anticoagulation vs. antiplatelet), stroke prevention, pseudoaneurysm monitoring, and long-term follow-up. Excludes intracranial dissection with subarachnoid hemorrhage (see SAH template), aortic dissection, and management of completed large territory ischemic stroke (see Acute Ischemic Stroke template for thrombolysis/thrombectomy protocols).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline hematologic assessment; thrombocytopenia affects antithrombotic choice; anemia evaluation
Electrolyte assessment; renal function for contrast imaging and medication dosing
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal electrolytes; eGFR adequate for contrast

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline coagulation; INR required before initiating anticoagulation; affects tPA eligibility if stroke present
Essential/Core Labs.target: INR <1.7 for tPA eligibility; baseline before anticoagulation

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline coagulation; required before heparin initiation
Hypoglycemia mimics stroke; required before tPA if stroke symptoms present
Cardiac ischemia evaluation; stress cardiomyopathy with acute stroke
Vascular risk assessment; statin decision-making for secondary prevention

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Inflammatory or vasculitic etiology; fibromuscular dysplasia workup
Inflammatory marker; vasculitis screen in young stroke workup
Liver function affects anticoagulant metabolism and dosing
Thyroid dysfunction as cardiovascular risk factor
Affects imaging choices (gadolinium contrast) and antithrombotic selection; pregnancy-associated dissection recognized etiology
Sympathomimetic use (cocaine, amphetamines) as dissection trigger
Coagulopathy evaluation; DIC screening if multi-organ involvement
Elevated in acute dissection; may support diagnosis when imaging equivocal; not diagnostic alone
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (though often elevated in acute dissection)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Blood products availability if interventional procedure or hemorrhagic complication

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Hyperhomocysteinemia as connective tissue and vascular risk factor in young dissection

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Connective tissue disorder panel (COL3A1 gene testing for vascular Ehlers-Danlos)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Recurrent dissections, family history of dissection, vascular fragility, easy bruising, thin translucent skin
Autoimmune vasculopathy screen in young stroke or recurrent dissection

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Antiphospholipid antibody panel (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, beta2-glycoprotein I)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Thrombophilia screening in young stroke with dissection; recurrent events

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Hypercoagulable panel (protein C, protein S, antithrombin III, Factor V Leiden, prothrombin gene mutation)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Young stroke workup; recurrent dissection or thrombosis history; family history of thrombophilia
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency associated with cervical artery dissection and connective tissue fragility
Suspected vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome; evaluates collagen structure
Syphilitic arteritis in young stroke workup

Essential/First-line.target: Exclude hemorrhage; identify early ischemic changes; rule out SAH from intracranial extension

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate with CT head; first-line for dissection diagnosis
Essential/First-line.target: Intimal flap, double lumen sign, tapered stenosis ("flame-shaped" occlusion), mural thickening, pseudoaneurysm, string sign
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); eGFR <30 (benefit outweighs risk in acute setting)

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if stroke symptoms; STAT if diagnosis uncertain
Essential/First-line.target: Acute ischemic infarct on DWI (restricted diffusion); infarct pattern suggesting artery-to-artery embolism; watershed vs embolic pattern
Rule out atrial fibrillation as alternative cardioembolic source; acute MI

Extended.timing: Within 24-48h; gold standard for intramural hematoma
Extended.target: Crescent sign (intramural hematoma on axial T1 fat-sat); vessel wall expansion; dissection flap; pseudoaneurysm
Intracranial extension of dissection; tandem lesion; distal embolism

Extended.timing: With CTA if extended stroke window (6-24h) or wake-up stroke
Extended.target: Ischemic penumbra assessment; mismatch between core infarct and hypoperfused tissue for thrombectomy decision
High-resistance flow pattern; absent or reduced flow; intimal flap; vessel wall hematoma (less sensitive than CTA/MRA)
Intracranial stenosis; distal flow changes; microembolic signals (HITS) on monitoring suggesting active embolization
Extended.contraindications: Absent temporal bone window (~10% of patients)

Extended.target: Rule out cardioembolism as alternative or concurrent etiology; PFO; valvular disease
Rule out atrial fibrillation as alternative stroke mechanism

Extended.item: CTA or MRA neck follow-up (3-6 months)
Extended.target: Recanalization (complete or partial), pseudoaneurysm stability or resolution, residual stenosis

Rare/Specialized.timing: If CTA/MRA equivocal; planned endovascular intervention
Rare/Specialized.target: Definitive vessel lumen assessment; intimal flap; double lumen; string-of-beads (FMD); pseudoaneurysm; stent planning
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Contrast allergy; severe renal impairment; coagulopathy; vessel fragility (vascular Ehlers-Danlos — relative contraindication)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If intracranial dissection vs. atherosclerosis vs. vasculitis unclear
Rare/Specialized.target: Vessel wall enhancement pattern; intramural hematoma; eccentric wall thickening distinguishes dissection from atherosclerosis

Rare/Specialized.timing: If connective tissue disorder suspected; multi-vessel dissection
Rare/Specialized.target: Additional dissections; aneurysms of aorta, renal, iliac arteries suggesting systemic arteriopathy

Rare/Specialized.item: Renal artery duplex or CTA abdomen
Rare/Specialized.timing: If fibromuscular dysplasia suspected (especially young women)
Rare/Specialized.target: Renal artery FMD (string-of-beads pattern); renal artery aneurysm

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute ischemic stroke within 4.5h of last known well due to dissection-related embolism

dosing.instructions: 0.9 mg/kg IV (max 90 mg); 10% as bolus over 1 min, remaining 90% infused over 60 min. Dissection is NOT a contraindication to IV tPA if within window

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Standard tPA exclusions: >4.5h from last known well; BP >185/110 despite treatment; platelets <100K; INR >1.7; active bleeding; intracranial hemorrhage; intracranial dissection with SAH
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Neuro checks q15min during infusion, q30min x 6h, then q1h x 18h; BP q15min x 2h, q30min x 6h; hold anticoagulants/antiplatelets 24h post-tPA

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute ischemic stroke with LVO from dissection; preferred if thrombectomy planned

dosing.instructions: 0.25 mg/kg IV single bolus (max 25 mg); preferred over alteplase if LVO planned for thrombectomy

Acute/Emergent.indication: Large vessel occlusion from dissection-related embolism or in-situ thrombosis; within 24h if eligible per DAWN/DEFUSE-3 criteria

dosing.instructions: Mechanical thrombectomy for LVO (ICA, M1, basilar); stenting of dissection considered on case-by-case basis

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Large established infarct (ASPECTS <6 in 0-6h window); no LVO; poor premorbid function (mRS >2)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Continuous neuro-ICU monitoring post-procedure; groin check; BP per post-thrombectomy protocol

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute dissection with high embolic risk: free-floating thrombus, crescendo TIA, recurrent embolic events despite antiplatelet, critical flow-limiting stenosis

doseOptions.orderSentence: Heparin 80 units/kg bolus IV then 18 units/kg/hr

dosing.instructions: Bolus 60-80 units/kg (max 5000 units); then infusion 12-18 units/kg/h; target aPTT 1.5-2.5x control (typically 60-80 sec)

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active hemorrhagic infarct; intracranial dissection with SAH; large completed infarct (hemorrhagic transformation risk); uncontrolled BP; active bleeding
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: aPTT q6h until stable, then q12-24h; platelets q3 days (HIT surveillance); daily neuro checks; signs of bleeding

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute dissection without stroke or with minor ischemic stroke; first-line antiplatelet per CADISS trial

dosing.instructions: 325 mg PO/PR loading dose; if tPA was given, wait 24h and obtain CT head before starting. Transition to maintenance 81-325 mg daily

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; true aspirin allergy; within 24h of tPA (wait for post-tPA CT)

Acute/Emergent.indication: BP control in acute dissection with stroke; target BP <185/110 if tPA candidate; permissive hypertension if no tPA

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV over 1-2 min; may repeat q10-20min; max 300 mg. Target: <185/110 pre-tPA; <180/105 post-tPA; <220/120 if no tPA

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Heart block (2nd/3rd degree); severe bradycardia; decompensated HF; asthma/severe COPD

Acute/Emergent.indication: Continuous BP control in acute dissection with stroke or severe hypertension

dosing.instructions: 5 mg/h IV infusion; increase by 2.5 mg/h q5-15min; max 15 mg/h

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: BP continuous monitoring; headache and flushing common

Acute/Emergent.indication: Isotonic fluid resuscitation and maintenance in acute dissection

dosing.instructions: Isotonic fluids; avoid hypotonic solutions (cerebral edema risk); avoid dextrose-containing fluids (hyperglycemia worsens ischemic outcomes)

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintain oxygenation in acute stroke from dissection

dosing.instructions: Only if SpO2 <94%; nasal cannula or mask as needed; target SpO2 >=94%

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: SpO2 continuous monitoring; avoid routine supplemental O2 if normoxic

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and neck pain from dissection; fever management (temperature >38C worsens ischemic outcomes)

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 4g/day (2g if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Temperature; LFTs if prolonged use; pain assessment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and neck pain from dissection if not on anticoagulation; short-term use only

dosing.instructions: 400-600 mg PO q6-8h PRN with food; max 2400 mg/day; limit to <7 days

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Concurrent anticoagulation (increased bleeding risk); GI bleeding history; renal impairment; concurrent aspirin (may reduce antiplatelet efficacy)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: GI symptoms; renal function; bleeding signs

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain (Horner syndrome-associated pain, persistent neck/face pain)

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg PO qHS; titrate by 300 mg q1-3 days; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; dizziness; peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting (vertebral dissection with posterior circulation symptoms)

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN nausea

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Vertigo from vertebral artery dissection with posterior circulation ischemia

dosing.instructions: 25 mg PO q6-8h PRN vertigo; short-term use only (may mask central symptoms)

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation; anticholinergic effects; monitor for central vertigo signs

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis if not on therapeutic anticoagulation and limited mobility

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start within 24-48h; hold if on therapeutic anticoagulation

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active bleeding; platelets <50K; CrCl <30 (use UFH 5000 units SC q8-12h instead)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis (non-pharmacologic); use in addition to or instead of pharmacologic prophylaxis

dosing.instructions: Apply to both lower extremities immediately on admission

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Acute DVT in lower extremity; severe peripheral vascular disease

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis for patients on antithrombotic therapy; stress ulcer prevention

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: C. difficile risk with prolonged use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: High-risk dissection with minor stroke (NIHSS <=3) or recurrent TIA on single antiplatelet; short-term use (21-90 days)

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg daily + Clopidogrel 75 mg daily x 21-90 days; load clopidogrel 300 mg if not previously on it; then transition to single antiplatelet

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Major stroke (NIHSS >3); high bleeding risk; planned surgery

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Bridge from IV heparin to oral anticoagulation; alternative to IV heparin in stable dissection with embolic risk

dosing.instructions: 1 mg/kg SC q12h; adjust for renal function (1 mg/kg daily if CrCl 15-30); bridge to warfarin if needed

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active bleeding; CrCl <15; HIT; large hemorrhagic infarct
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Anti-Xa levels (target 0.5-1.0 IU/mL); platelets q3 days; renal function

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Dissection with high embolic risk when anticoagulation chosen over antiplatelet; CADISS trial showed equivalent outcomes

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily (2-3 mg if elderly, low weight, or drug interactions); target INR 2.0-3.0; overlap with heparin bridge until INR therapeutic x 2 consecutive days

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active bleeding; pregnancy (teratogenic); severe hepatic disease; inability to monitor INR
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: INR daily until stable, then weekly, then monthly; diet counseling (vitamin K consistency); bleeding signs

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Refractory ischemia despite optimal antithrombotic therapy; symptomatic recurrent stenosis; expanding pseudoaneurysm with embolic events

dosing.instructions: Endovascular stenting of dissected segment; case-by-case basis; dual antiplatelet pre- and post-procedure

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Active hemorrhage; vascular Ehlers-Danlos (extreme caution — vessel fragility); vessel too tortuous for access
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-procedure: continuous neuro monitoring x 24h; dual antiplatelet compliance; follow-up imaging at 1, 3, 6 months

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute cerebral edema from large territory infarct due to dissection-related stroke

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus for acute herniation; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h maintenance

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum osmolality (hold if >320 mOsm/kg); osmolar gap; renal function; I/O

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Acute herniation from massive stroke due to dissection-related occlusion

doseOptions.orderSentence: Hypertonic Saline 23.4% 30 mL IV bolus over 15 min

dosing.instructions: 30 mL IV bolus via central line over 10-20 min for acute herniation
dosing.orderSentence: Hypertonic Saline 23.4% 30 mL IV bolus over 15 min

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum sodium (target 145-155 mEq/L); osmolality; central line integrity

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Malignant MCA infarction from carotid dissection with complete ICA occlusion and poor collaterals

dosing.instructions: Surgery within 48h of onset; age <60 preferred; >50% MCA territory infarct; reduces mortality from 70-80% to ~20%

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Post-operative neuro checks; ICP monitoring; wound care

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Long-term secondary stroke prevention post-dissection; first-line per CADISS trial equivalence data

dosing.instructions: 81 mg PO daily preferred for long-term use; 325 mg daily acceptable; duration minimum 3-6 months; many neurologists continue indefinitely if vascular risk factors present

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; true aspirin allergy
Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.monitoring: GI symptoms; annual CBC; bleeding assessment at follow-up

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Alternative antiplatelet for aspirin-intolerant patients; long-term secondary prevention post-dissection

dosing.instructions: 75 mg PO daily; duration minimum 3-6 months; if aspirin intolerant, may use long-term

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active pathologic bleeding; hypersensitivity to clopidogrel

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Dissection with concurrent atrial fibrillation; alternative anticoagulant if warfarin not preferred

dosing.instructions: 5 mg PO BID standard dose; 2.5 mg BID if >=2 of: age >=80, weight <=60 kg, Cr >=1.5; for concurrent AF or physician preference for anticoagulation strategy

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active pathologic bleeding; prosthetic heart valve
Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Renal function q6-12 months; bleeding signs; CBC

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Vascular risk reduction; secondary stroke prevention in dissection patients with atherosclerotic risk factors

dosing.instructions: 40-80 mg PO daily; high-intensity statin therapy for secondary stroke prevention

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.monitoring: LFTs at 12 weeks then annually; lipid panel at 4-12 weeks; CK if myalgia

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Blood pressure management for secondary stroke prevention; target BP <130/80 after acute phase

dosing.instructions: Start 5-10 mg PO daily; titrate to 20-40 mg daily; target BP <130/80

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Bilateral renal artery stenosis; angioedema history; pregnancy
Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Cr and K+ at 1-2 weeks; BP at follow-up visits

Disease-Modifying / Chronic Therapies.indication: Alternative or adjunctive antihypertensive for secondary stroke prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; max 10 mg daily

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation (stroke team) for dissection confirmation, antithrombotic strategy, and stroke workup coordination
Neurointerventional/endovascular consultation for large vessel occlusion thrombectomy or stenting consideration in refractory dissection
Neurosurgery consultation for malignant cerebral edema, posterior fossa stroke with hydrocephalus, or expanding pseudoaneurysm requiring surgical management
Vascular neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks for antithrombotic reassessment and follow-up imaging planning
Genetics consultation if suspected connective tissue disorder (vascular Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan, Loeys-Dietz) given recurrent dissections, family history, or clinical features
Rheumatology consultation if vasculitis or autoimmune arteriopathy suspected based on lab findings or imaging
Cardiology consultation for newly detected atrial fibrillation or PFO evaluation if concurrent cardioembolic source suspected
Speech-language pathology (SLP) for dysphagia screening before PO intake if stroke present; also evaluate for lower cranial nerve palsy (vagus, hypoglossal) from carotid dissection
Physical therapy for early mobilization (24-48h), gait training, and balance assessment if stroke-related deficits present
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, upper extremity function, and adaptive strategies if stroke-related deficits present
Ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology referral if persistent Horner syndrome for ptosis evaluation and baseline assessment
Pain management referral for refractory neck/head pain not responding to standard analgesics
Social work for discharge planning, insurance coordination, DME, and caregiver support

Patient Instructions.item: Call 911 immediately if new or worsening symptoms: sudden weakness, numbness, vision changes, speech difficulty, severe headache, loss of balance (may indicate stroke from dissection)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology (minimum 2 weeks; Horner syndrome may affect vision)
Take all antithrombotic medications exactly as prescribed; do NOT stop aspirin, clopidogrel, or anticoagulant without medical advice (stopping increases stroke risk)

Avoid high-risk neck activities: vigorous chiropractic manipulation, extreme cervical extension/rotation, contact sports, roller coasters, heavy lifting with Valsalva (may worsen dissection or cause recurrence)
Report new neck pain, headache (especially pulsatile), drooping eyelid, double vision, or pulsatile tinnitus as these may indicate dissection extension or new dissection
If on warfarin: maintain consistent vitamin K intake; attend all INR monitoring appointments; report any signs of bleeding (bruising, blood in stool/urine, gum bleeding)
Follow-up imaging (CTA or MRA neck) scheduled at 3-6 months to assess vessel healing; do NOT skip this appointment
Follow-up appointment with neurology in 2-4 weeks for treatment reassessment; primary care in 4 weeks for vascular risk factor management
Avoid straining and heavy lifting (>20 lbs) for 4-6 weeks to reduce risk of dissection propagation
Gradual return to light exercise after 2-4 weeks with physician clearance; avoid high-impact sports for 3-6 months minimum

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Avoid chiropractic cervical manipulation permanently given dissection history (recurrence risk)
Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg for secondary stroke prevention
Smoking cessation (absolute) as smoking impairs vascular healing and increases recurrence risk
Moderate alcohol use only (<=1 drink/day women, <=2 drinks/day men); excess alcohol increases bleeding risk on antithrombotics
Mediterranean or DASH diet for vascular risk reduction
Regular moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (30-40 min, 3-5 days/week) after medical clearance; avoid contact sports and extreme neck positions
Weight management (BMI 18.5-24.9) for vascular risk reduction
Glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) if diabetic to reduce vascular risk
Avoid oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy without neurology input given vascular event history
Home blood pressure monitoring with log for physician review at follow-up visits
Stress management and emotional support; anxiety and depression common after young stroke diagnosis

differential.features: Older patient; vascular risk factors (HTN, DM, hyperlipidemia, smoking); calcified plaque on imaging; gradual onset; no neck pain
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (calcified plaque vs. intimal flap/hematoma); MRI fat-sat (no intramural hematoma)

differential.features: Young-middle aged women; "string-of-beads" appearance on angiography; may coexist with dissection; renal artery involvement
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (string-of-beads vs. smooth tapering); renal artery imaging; FMD can cause dissection

differential.features: Shelf-like projection in posterior carotid bulb; recurrent stroke in young patients; no neck pain or Horner syndrome
Multifocal stenoses; constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, arthralgias); elevated ESR/CRP; multi-territory strokes
differential.tests: ESR, CRP, ANA, ANCA; vessel wall MRI (concentric enhancement vs. eccentric in dissection); possible brain/meningeal biopsy

differential.features: Thunderclap headache; multifocal segmental vasoconstriction; triggered by vasoactive drugs, postpartum; spontaneous resolution
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (diffuse segmental narrowing vs. focal dissection); serial imaging showing resolution at 12 weeks

differential.features: Acute headache (worst headache if rupture); focal mass effect; SAH on CT
differential.tests: CT head (SAH); CTA (saccular aneurysm vs. dissecting pseudoaneurysm); LP

differential.features: Episodic; visual or sensory aura preceding headache; family history; stereotyped attacks; young patient
differential.tests: Clinical history (recurrent stereotyped episodes); normal MRI DWI (no infarct); dissection can mimic migraine

differential.features: Periorbital pain with autonomic features (tearing, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea, partial Horner); episodic pattern
differential.tests: Clinical pattern (brief attacks in clusters); Horner syndrome in cluster is transient; CTA/MRA to exclude dissection if first presentation

differential.features: Irregular rhythm; multiple vascular territory infarcts; no neck pain or local signs
differential.tests: ECG/telemetry (AF); TTE/TEE (PFO, thrombus); CTA neck (normal vessels, no dissection)

differential.features: Headache, papilledema, seizures; may have focal deficits; hypercoagulable state; postpartum
differential.tests: CT/MR venography (venous thrombosis); CTA arterial phase normal

differential.features: Self-limited neck pain and tenderness over carotid; no neurologic deficits; perivascular inflammation on imaging
differential.tests: Ultrasound/CTA (perivascular inflammation without intimal flap or intramural hematoma); self-resolves in 2 weeks

differential.features: Neck pain after trauma/exertion; no neurologic deficits; no Horner syndrome; normal vascular imaging
differential.tests: Clinical exam (muscular tenderness, full neuro exam normal); CTA/MRA if dissection concern

evidence.recommendation: Antiplatelet vs. anticoagulation equivalent for stroke prevention in cervical dissection
evidence.source: CADISS trial (Markus et al. Lancet Neurology 2015)

evidence.recommendation: CADISS extended follow-up: no difference in recurrent stroke or death at 1 year
evidence.source: CADISS investigators (J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2019)

evidence.recommendation: IV tPA safe and effective in dissection-related stroke; cervical dissection is NOT a contraindication
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines (Powers et al.); observational data

evidence.recommendation: Antithrombotic therapy recommended for at least 3-6 months post-dissection
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2014 Stroke Prevention Guidelines; Expert consensus

evidence.recommendation: CTA and MRA with fat saturation are first-line imaging for cervical dissection diagnosis
evidence.source: Debette et al. Lancet Neurology 2015 (review); Provenzale and Sarikaya Radiology 2009

evidence.recommendation: Intramural hematoma best seen on T1 fat-saturated MRI (crescent sign)
evidence.source: Debette and Leys NEJM 2009

evidence.recommendation: Fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common arteriopathy associated with cervical dissection
evidence.source: Olin et al. Circulation 2011; Debette et al. Lancet Neurology 2015

evidence.recommendation: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (COL3A1 mutations) increases dissection risk; avoid catheter angiography if possible
evidence.source: Pepin et al. NEJM 2000; Byers Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Vascular Type (GeneReviews)

evidence.recommendation: Thrombectomy for LVO from dissection follows standard acute stroke criteria
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines; MR CLEAN, DAWN, DEFUSE-3 trials (dissection etiology subgroup data)

evidence.recommendation: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) for minor stroke/high-risk TIA applicable to dissection-related minor stroke
evidence.source: CHANCE trial (Wang et al. NEJM 2013); POINT trial

evidence.recommendation: Cervical dissection accounts for 10-25% of ischemic strokes in young adults (<50 years)
evidence.source: Debette and Leys NEJM 2009; Schievink NEJM 2001

evidence.recommendation: Annual recurrence rate of cervical dissection is approximately 1% per year
evidence.source: Schievink et al. Neurology 1994; Debette et al. Stroke 2011

evidence.recommendation: Chiropractic cervical manipulation associated with increased cervical dissection risk
evidence.source: Cassidy et al. Spine 2008; Rothwell et al. Stroke 2001 (association debated but avoidance recommended)

evidence.recommendation: Pseudoaneurysm monitoring with serial imaging; most stabilize; intervention for symptomatic expansion
evidence.source: Expert consensus; Touze et al. Stroke 2001

evidence.recommendation: Follow-up vascular imaging at 3-6 months to assess recanalization and guide antithrombotic duration
evidence.source: AHA/ASA guidelines; expert consensus

evidence.recommendation: Permissive hypertension (up to 220/120 if no tPA) in dissection-related stroke without thrombolysis
evidence.source: AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines

evidence.recommendation: Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis) is a classic presentation of carotid dissection; present in ~50% of carotid dissections
evidence.source: Mokri et al. Ann Neurol 1986; Debette and Leys NEJM 2009

evidence.recommendation: Decompressive craniectomy for malignant MCA edema from dissection-related ICA occlusion follows standard protocols
evidence.source: DESTINY, DECIMAL, HAMLET pooled analysis

evidence.recommendation: Pregnancy and postpartum period are recognized risk factors for cervical artery dissection
evidence.source: Kelly et al. Neurology 2014; Arnold et al. Neurology 2006

evidence.recommendation: High-intensity statin therapy for secondary stroke prevention in patients with atherosclerotic risk factors post-dissection
evidence.source: SPARCL trial (Amarenco et al. NEJM 2006); AHA/ASA 2021

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (NIHSS, cranial nerves, Horner syndrome)
monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h acutely, then q4h x 48h, then q shift; outpatient at each visit
monitoring.action: If NIHSS increases >=4: STAT CT head; call stroke team; reassess antithrombotic strategy

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 24h, then q4h; outpatient at each visit
monitoring.action: Titrate antihypertensives; avoid SBP <100 (hypoperfusion risk in stenosed vessel)
Cardiology consult; anticoagulation if AF detected
Adjust heparin infusion rate per protocol

monitoring.frequency: Daily until stable, then weekly, then monthly
monitoring.action: Adjust warfarin dose; bridge with heparin if subtherapeutic and high risk

monitoring.item: Platelet count (HIT surveillance if on heparin)
monitoring.action: HIT screen (PF4 antibody); switch to argatroban or bivalirudin if positive

monitoring.item: Follow-up vascular imaging (CTA or MRA neck)
monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-diagnosis; then 12 months if residual abnormality
monitoring.action: If worsening: neurovascular conference; consider intervention; adjust antithrombotic

monitoring.frequency: q24-48h if contrast given; q3-6 months if on DOAC
monitoring.action: Hydration; adjust medication dosing; hold nephrotoxic agents

monitoring.frequency: q6h x 48h (q1h if insulin drip) if stroke present

monitoring.action: NPO until formal SLP evaluation; consider NG tube

monitoring.frequency: Fasting within 24-48h; repeat at 4-12 weeks on statin

monitoring.action: SSRI initiation; psychology/psychiatry referral; peer support

disposition.criteria: Dissection without stroke or with minor stroke (NIHSS 0-3); stable exam over 24h observation; antithrombotic therapy initiated and tolerated; adequate home support; reliable outpatient follow-up arranged; imaging follow-up scheduled; prescriptions filled; patient education complete

Dissection with moderate stroke (NIHSS 4-15); dissection requiring IV heparin initiation and aPTT monitoring; new dissection requiring observation for stroke development; incomplete workup; dysphagia requiring NPO or modified diet; pain requiring IV medications
